declarations.comments: the mode parameter passed to `access` and `accessSync`.
declarations.title: AccessMode

declarations.comments:
the file is visible to the calling process. 
This is useful for determining if a file exists, but says nothing about rwx permissions. Default if no mode is specified.
declarations.title: f_OK

declarations.comments: the file can be read by the calling process.
declarations.title: r_OK

declarations.comments: the file can be written by the calling process.
declarations.title: w_OK

declarations.comments: the file can be executed by the calling process. This has no effect on Windows (will behave like fs.constants.F_OK).
declarations.title: x_OK

declarations.comments: A constant used in `copyFile`.
declarations.title: CopyMode

declarations.comments: If present, the copy operation will fail with an error if the destination path already exists.
declarations.title: copyFile_EXCL

declarations.comments: If present, the copy operation will attempt to create a copy-on-write reflink. If the underlying platform does not support copy-on-write, then a fallback copy mechanism is used.
declarations.title: copyFile_FICLONE

declarations.comments: If present, the copy operation will attempt to create a copy-on-write reflink. If the underlying platform does not support copy-on-write, then the operation will fail with an error.
declarations.title: copyFile_FICLONE_FORCE

declarations.comments:
Convert a `FileFlags` to a `String` in the format expected by the Node.js
filesystem API.
declarations.title: fileFlagsToNode

declarations.comments:
A `Perm` value specifies what is allowed to be done with a particular
file by a particular class of user — that is, whether it is
readable, writable, and/or executable. It has a `Semiring` instance, which
allows you to combine permissions:

- `(+)` adds `Perm` values together. For example, `read + write` means
  "readable and writable".
- `(*)` masks permissions. It can be thought of as selecting only the
   permissions that two `Perm` values have in common. For example:
   `(read + write) * (write + execute) == write`.

You can think also of a `Perm` value as a subset of the set
`{ read, write, execute }`; then, `(+)` and `(*)` represent set union and
intersection respectively.
declarations.title: Perm

declarations.comments:
Create a `Perm` value. The arguments represent the readable, writable, and
executable permissions, in that order.
declarations.title: mkPerm

declarations.comments:
No permissions. This is the identity of the `Semiring` operation `(+)`
for `Perm`; that is, it is the same as `zero`.
declarations.title: none

declarations.comments: The "readable" permission.
declarations.title: read

declarations.comments: The "writable" permission.
declarations.title: write

declarations.comments: The "executable" permission.
declarations.title: execute

declarations.comments:
All permissions: readable, writable, and executable. This is the identity
of the `Semiring` operation `(*)` for `Perm`; that is, it is the same as
`one`.
declarations.title: all

declarations.comments:
A `Perms` value includes all the permissions information about a
particular file or directory, by storing a `Perm` value for each of the
file owner, the group, and any other users.
declarations.title: Perms

declarations.comments:
Create a `Perms` value. The arguments represent the owner's, group's, and
other users' permission sets, respectively.
declarations.title: mkPerms

declarations.comments:
Attempt to parse a `Perms` value from a `String` containing an octal
integer. For example,
`permsFromString "0644" == Just (mkPerms (read + write) read read)`.
declarations.title: permsFromString

declarations.comments:
Convert a `Perms` value to an octal string, in a format similar to that
accepted by `chmod`. For example:
`permsToString (mkPerms (read + write) read read) == "0644"`
declarations.title: permsToString

declarations.comments: Convert a `Perms` value to an `Int`, via `permsToString`.
declarations.title: permsToInt

declarations.comments:
Returns true if the <fs.Stats> object describes a file system directory.
If the `fs.Stats`> object was obtained from `fs.lstat()`, 
this method will always return `false``. This is because `fs.lstat()` 
returns information about a symbolic link itself and not the path to which it resolves.
declarations.title: isDirectory

declarations.comments: The numeric identifier of the device containing the file.
declarations.title: dev

declarations.comments: The file system specific "Inode" number for the file.
declarations.title: inode

declarations.comments: A bit-field describing the file type and mode.
declarations.title: mode

declarations.comments: The number of hard-links that exist for the file.
declarations.title: nlink

declarations.comments: The numeric user identifier of the user that owns the file (POSIX).
declarations.title: uid

declarations.comments: The numeric group identifier of the group that owns the file (POSIX).
declarations.title: gid

declarations.comments: A numeric device identifier if the file represents a device.
declarations.title: rdev

declarations.comments:
The size of the file in bytes.
If the underlying file system does not support getting the size of the file, this will be 0.
declarations.title: size

declarations.comments: The file system block size for i/o operations.
declarations.title: blkSize

declarations.comments: The number of blocks allocated for this file.
declarations.title: blocks

declarations.comments:
Create a Writable stream which writes data to the specified file, using
the default options.
declarations.title: createWriteStream

declarations.comments:
Create a Writable stream which writes data to the specified file.
Unused options should not be specified. Some options
(e.g. `flags`, `encoding`, and `mode`) should convert their 
PureScript values to the corresponding JavaScript ones:
```
filePath # createWriteStream'
  { flags: fileFlagsToNode R
  , encoding: encodingToNode UTF8
  , mode: permsToInt Perms.all
  }
```
declarations.title: createWriteStream'

declarations.comments:
Create a Writable stream which writes data to the specified file
descriptor, using the default options.
declarations.title: fdCreateWriteStream

declarations.comments:
Create a Writable stream which writes data to the specified file descriptor.
Unused options should not be specified. Some options
(e.g. `flags`, `encoding`, and `mode`) should convert their 
PureScript values to the corresponding JavaScript ones:
```
filePath # fdCreateWriteStream'
  { flags: fileFlagsToNode R
  , encoding: encodingToNode UTF8
  , mode: permsToInt Perms.all
  }
```
declarations.title: fdCreateWriteStream'

declarations.comments:
Create a Readable stream which reads data to the specified file, using
the default options.
declarations.title: createReadStream

declarations.comments:
Create a Readable stream which reads data from the specified file.
Unused options should not be specified. Some options
(e.g. `flags`, `encoding`, and `mode`) should convert their 
PureScript values to the corresponding JavaScript ones:
```
filePath # createReadStream'
  { flags: fileFlagsToNode R
  , encoding: encodingToNode UTF8
  , mode: permsToInt Perms.all
  }
```
declarations.title: createReadStream'

declarations.comments:
Create a Readable stream which reads data to the specified file
descriptor, using the default options.
declarations.title: fdCreateReadStream

declarations.comments:
Create a Readable stream which reads data to the specified file descriptor.
Unused options should not be specified. Some options
(e.g. `flags`, `encoding`, and `mode`) should convert their 
PureScript values to the corresponding JavaScript ones:
```
filePath # fdCreateReadStream'
  { flags: fileFlagsToNode R
  , encoding: encodingToNode UTF8
  , mode: permsToInt Perms.all
  }
```
declarations.title: fdCreateReadStream'
